div.head:
To His Grace
PHILIP,
DUKE and MARQUIS of
WHARTON, &c.
div.p: IT has ever been the Custom of Poets to shelter Productions of this Nature under the Patronage of the brightest Men of their Time; and 'tis observ'd, that the Muses always met the kindest Reception from Persons of the greatest Merit. The World will do me Justice as to the Choice of my Patron, but will, I fear, blame

head.hi: DEDICATION.

div.p: blame my rash Attempt, in daring to Address Your Grace, and offer at a Work too difficult for our ablest Pens, viz. an Encomium on Your Grace: I have no Plea against such just Reflections, but the Disadvantage of Education, and the Privilege of my Sex.

If Your Grace discovers a Genius so surprising in this Dawn of Life, what must your riper Years produce? Your Grace has already been distinguish'd in a most peculiar Manner, being the first Young Nobleman that ever was admitted into a House of Peers before he reached the Age of One and Twenty: But Your Grace's Judgment and Eloquence soon convinced that August Assembly, that the excelling Gifts of Nature ought not to be confin'd to Time. We hope the Example which Ireland has set, will shortly be followed by an English House of Lords, and Your Grace made a Member of that Body, to which You will be so Conspicuous an Ornament.
Your good Sense, and real Love for your Country, taught Your Grace to persevere in the Principles of your Glorious

head.hi: DEDICATION.

div.p: rious Ancestors, by adhering to the Defender of our Religion and Laws: and the penetrating Wisdom of Your Royal Master, saw you merited your Honours ere he conferr'd them. It is one of the greatest Glories of a Monarch, to distinguish where to bestow his Favours; and the World must do ours Justice, by owning Your Grace's Titles most deservedly worn.

It is with the greatest Pleasure imaginable the Friends of Liberty see You pursuing the Steps of Your Noble Father: Your Courteous, Affable Temper, free from Pride and Ostentation, makes Your Name ador'd in the Country, and enables Your Grace to carry what Point You please. The late Lord Wharton will be still remember'd by every Lover of his Country, which never felt a greater Shock than what his Death occasion'd: Their Grief had been inconsolable, if Heaven, out of its wonted Beneficence to this Favourite Isle, had not transmitted all his shining Qualities to you, and Phenix like, raised up one Patriot out of the Ashes of another.
That

head.hi: DEDICATION.

div.p: That Your Grace has a high Esteem for Learning, particularly appears by the large Progress you have made therein: and your Love for the Muses shews a Sweetness of Temper, and Generous Humanity, peculiar to the Greatness of Your Soul; for such Virtues reign not in the Breast of every Man of Quality.

Defer no longer then, my Lord, to charm the World with the Beauty of your Numbers, and shew the Poet, as you have done the Orator; convince our unthinking Britous, by what vile Arts France lost her Liberty; and teach 'em to avoid their own Misfortunes, as well as to weep over Henry IV. who (if it were possible for him to know) would forgive the bold Assassin's Hand, for the Honour of having his Fall celebrated by Your Grace's Pen.

To be distinguish'd by Persons of Your Grace's Character, is not only the highest Ambition, but the greatest Reputation to an Author; and it is not the least of my Vanities, to have it known to the Publick I had Your Grace's Leave to prefix Your Name to this Comedy. I

head.hi: DEDICATION.

div.p: I wish I were capable to cloath the following Scenes in such a Dress, as might be worthy to appear before Your Grace, and draw Your Attention as much as Your Grace's admirable Qualifications do that of all Mankind; but the Muses, like most Females, are least liberal to their own Sex.

All I dare say in Favour of this Piece is, that the Plot is entirely New, and the Incidents wholly owing to my own Invention; not borrow'd from our own, or translated from the Works of any Foreign Poet; so that they have at least the Charm of Novelty to recommend 'em: If they are so lucky in some leisure Hour to give Your Grace the Least Diversion, they will answer the utmost Ambition of, my Lord,

div.head: RROLOGUE,
div.p: By a GENTLEMAN.

sp.speaker: Spoken by Mrs. THURMOND.
sp.l: TO-Night we come upon a bold Design,
To try to please without one borrow'd Line:
Our Plot is new, and regularly clear,
And not one single Tittle from Moliere:
O'er bury'd Poets we with Caution tread,
And Parish Sextons leave to rob the Dead.
For you, bright British Fair, in hopes to charm ye,
We bring To-night a Lover from the Army:
You know the Soldiers have the strangest Arts,
Such a Proportion of prevailing Parts,
You'd think that they rid Post to Womens Hearts.
I wonder whence they draw their bold Pretence;
We do not chuse them sure for our Defence:
That Plea is both impolitick and wrong,
And only suits such Dames as want a Tongue.
Is it their Eloquence and fine Address?
The Softness of their Language?—Nothing less.
Is it their Courage, that they bravely dare
To storm the Sex at once?—Egad, 'tis there:
They act by us as in the rough Campaign,
Unmindful of Repulses, charge again;
They Mine and Countermine, resolv'd to win,
And, if a Breach is made—they will come in.
You'll think, by what we have of Soldiers said,
Our Female Wit was in the Service bred;
But she is to the hardy Toil a Stranger,
She loves the Cloth indeed, but hates the Danger;
Yet to this Circle of the Brave and Gay,
She bid me for her good Intentions say,
She hopes you'll not reduce her to Half-Pay.
Then will you let our Manufacture fall?
Would you the Honour of our Nation raise,
Keep English Credit up, and English Plays.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a WIFE.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Colonel Fainwell and Freeman over a Bottle.

sp.speaker: FREEMAN.
sp.l: COME, Colonel, His Majesty's Health—You are as melancholly as if you were in Love; I wish some of the Beauties at Bath ha'n't snapt your Heart.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why faith, Freeman, there is something in't; I have seen a Lady at Bath, who has kindled such a Flame in me, that all the Waters there can't quench.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Women, like some poisonous Animals, carry their Antidote about 'em:—Is she not to be had, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That's a difficult Question to answer; however, I resolve to try: Perhaps you may be able to serve me; you Merchants know one another—The Lady told me herself she was under the Charge of four Persons.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Odso! 'tis Mrs. Ann Lovely.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The same; do you know her?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Know her! Ay—Faith, Colonel, your Condition is more desperate than you imagine; why she is the Talk and Pity of the whole Town; and it is the Opinion of the Learned, that she must die a Maid.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Say you so? That's somewhat odd, in this charitable City—She's a Woman, I hope.

sp.speaker: Free.
Col.
sp.l: But may one trust him?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: With your Life; I have Obligations enough upon him, to make him do any thing; I serve him with Wine. [Knocks.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Nay, I know him pretty well my self; I once us'd to frequent a Club that was kept here.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Gentlemen, d'you call?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ay, send up your Master.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Do you know any of this Lady's Guardians,
Freeman?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Yes, I know two of them very well.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Here comes one will give you an Account of them all—Mr. Sackbut, we sent for you to take a Glass with us. 'Tis a Maxim among the Friends of the Bottle, that as long as the Master is in Company one may be sure of good Wine.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Sir, you shall be sure to have as good Wine as you send in—Colonel, your most humble Servant; you are welcome to Town.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I thank you, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: I am as glad to see you, as I should a Hundred Tun of French Claret Custom-free—my Service to you, Sir. [Drinks.] You don't look so merry as you us'd to do; are you not well, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: He has got a Woman in his Head, Landlord, can you help him?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: If 'tis in my Power, I shan't scruple to serve my Friend.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Tis one Perquisite of your Calling.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Ay, at t'other End of the Town, where you Officers use, Women are good Forcers of Trade; a well-custom'd House, a handsome Bar-keeper, with clean obliging Drawers, soon get the Master an Estate; but our Citizens seldom do any thing but cheat within the Walls—But as to the Lady, Colonel; point you at Particulars, or have you a good Champagne Stomack? Are you in full Pay, or reduc'd, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Reduc'd, reduc'd, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: To the miserable Condition of a Lover!

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Pish! That's preferrable to Half-pay; a Woman's Resolution may break before the Peace; push her home, Colonel, there's no parlying with that Sex.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Were the Lady her own Mistress, I have some Reasons to believe I should soon command in Chief.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You know Mrs. Lovely, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Know her! Ay, poor Nancy; I have carried her to School many a frosty Morning. Alas, if she's the Woman, I pity you, Colonel: Her Father, my old Master, was the most whimsical, out-of-the-way temper'd Man, I ever heard of, as you will guess by his last Will and Testament—This was his only Child: I have heard him wish her dead a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: He hated Posterity, you must know, and wish'd the World were to expire with himself—He used to swear, if she had been a Boy, he would have qualify'd him for the Opera.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Tis a very unnatural Resolution in a Father.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: He dy'd worth Thirty thousand Pounds, which he left to this Daughter, provided she married with the Consent of her Guardians: But that she might be sure never to do so, he left her in the Care of four Men, as opposite to each other as Light and Darkness: Each has his quarterly Rule, and three Months in a Year she is oblig'd to be subject to each of their Humours, and they are pretty different, I assure you—She is just come from Bath.A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Twas there I saw her.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Ay, Sir, the last Quarter was her Beau Guardian's—She appears in all publick Places during his Reign.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: She visited a Lady who boarded in the same House with me: I lik'd her Person, and found an Opportunity to tell her so: She reply'd, she had no Objection to mine; but if I could not reconcile Contradictions, I must not think of her, for that she was condemned to the Caprice of four Persons, who never yet agreed in any one thing, and she was oblig'd to please them all.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: 'Tis most true, Sir; I'll give you a short Description of the Men, and leave you to judge of the poor Lady's Condition. One is a kind of a Virtuoso, a silly, half-witted Fellow, but positive and surly; fond of nothing but what is Antique and Foreign, and wears his Cloaths of the Fashion of the last Century; doats upon Travellers, and believes Sir John Mandiville more than the Bible.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That must be a rare old Fellow!

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Another is a Change-Broker; a Fellow that will out-lie the Devil for the Advantage of Stock, and cheat his Father that got him in a Bargain: He is a great Stickler for Trade and hates every thing that wears a Sword.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: He is a great Admirer of the Dutch Management, and swears they understand Trade better than any Nation under the Sun.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: The Third is an old Beau, that has May in his Fancy and Dress, but December in his Face and his Heels;
he

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: These are pretty opposite to one another, truly! And the fourth, what is he, Landlord?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: A very rigid Quaker, whose Quarter begun this Day—I saw Mrs. Lovely go in not above two Hours ago—Sir Philip set her down. What think you now, Colonel, is not the poor Lady to be pity'd?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ay, and rescued too, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: In my Opinion, that's impossible.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There is nothing impossible to a Lover. What would not a Man attempt for a fine Woman and Thirty Thousand Pounds? Besides, my Honour is at Stake; I promis'd to deliver her—and she bad me win her, and take her.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: That's fair, faith.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: If it depended upon Knight-Errantry, I should not doubt your setting free the Damsel; but to have Avarice, Impertinence, Hypocrifie, and Pride, at once to deal with, requires more Cunning than generally attends a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My Fancy tells me I shall come off with Glory; I resolve to try, however.—Do you know all the Guardians, Mr. Sackbut?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Very well, Sir, they all use my House.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And will you assist me, if occasion be?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: In every thing I can, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I'll answer for him; and whatever I can serve you in, you may depend on. I know Mr. Periwinkle and Mr. Tradelove; the latter has a very great Opinion of my Interest Abroad.—I happen'd to have a Letter from a Correspondent two Hours before the News arrived of the French King's Death; I communicated it to him; upon which he bought up all the Stock he could, and what with that, and some Wagers he laid, he told me, he had got to the Tune of Five Hundred Pounds; so that I am much in his good Graces.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.l: I don't know but you may be of Service to me, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: If I can, command me, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Is it not possible to find a Suit of Cloaths ready made at some of these Sale Shops, fit to rig out a Beau, think you, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: O hang 'em—No, Colonel, they keep nothing ready-made that a Gentleman would be seen in: But I can fit you with a Suit of Cloaths, if you'd make a Figure—Velvet and Gold Brocade—they were pawn'd to me by a French Count, who had been stript at Play, and wanted Money to carry him home; he promis'd to send for them, but I have heard nothing from him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: He has not fed upon Frogs long enough yet to recover his Loss; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ha, ha,—Well, those Cloaths will do, Mr. Sackbut— tho' we must have three or four Fellows in tawdry Liveries; those can be procur'd, I hope.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
Egad, I have a Brother come from the
West-Indies,
that can match you; and, for Expedition sake, you shall have his Servants; there's a Black, a Tawny-moor, and a Frenchman; they don't speak one Word of English, so can make no Mistake.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Excellent—Egad, I shall look like an Indian Prince. First I'll attack my Beau-Guardian; where lives he?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Faith, somewhere about St. James 's; tho' to say in what Street, I cannot; but any Chairman will tell you where Sir Philip Modelove lives.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Oh! you'll find him in the Park at Eleven every Day; at least I never pass'd thro' at that Hour without seeing him there.—But what do you intend?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: To address him in his own Way, and find what he designs to do with the Lady.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: And what then?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Nay, that I can't tell, but I shall take my Measures accordingly.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Well, 'tis a mad Undertaking, in my Mind; but here's to your Success, Colonel. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Tis something out of the Way, I confess; but Fortune may chance to smile, and I succeed—Come, Landlord, let me see those Cloaths. Freeman, I shall expect you'll leave Word with Mr. Sackbut, where one may find you upon occasion; and send my Equipage of India immediately, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Immediately.

l.hi: Bold was the Man who ventur'd first to Sea,
But the first vent'ring Lovers bolder were:
The Path of Love's a dark and dangerous Way,
Without a Landmark, or one friendly Star,
And he that runs the Risque, deserves the Fair.

div.head: SCENE II. Prim's
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Lovely and her Maid Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Bless me, Madam! why do you fret and teaze your self so? This is giving them the Advantage with a Witness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Must I be condemned all my Life to the preposterous Humours of other People; and pointed at by every Boy in Town?—Oh! I could tear my Flesh, and curse the Hour I was born.—Is it not monstrously ridiculous, that they should desire to impose their Quaking Dress upon me at these Years? When I was a Child, no matter what they made me wear; but now—

sp.speaker: Betty.
Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Then I must never expect one Moment's Ease; she has rung such a Peal in my Ears already, that I shan't have the right Use of them this Month—What can I do?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: What can you not do, if you will but give your Mind to it? Marry, Madam.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: What! and have my Fortune go to build Churches and Hospitals?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Why, let it go—If the Colonel loves you, as he pretends, he'll marry you without a Fortune, Madam; and I assure you, a Colonel's Lady is no despicable thing; a Colonel's Post will maintain you like a Gentlewoman, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: So you wou'd advise me to give up my own Fortune, and throw my self upon the Colonel's.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: I would advise you to make your self easie, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: That's not the Way, I am sure. No, no, Girl, there are certain Ingredients to be mingled with Matrimony, without which, I may as well change for the worse as for the better. When the Woman has Fortune enough to make the Man happy, if he has either Honour or Good Manners, he'll make her easie. Love makes but a slovenly Figure in that House, where Poverty keeps the Door.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: And so you resolve to die a Maid, do you Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: Or have it in my Power to make the Man I love, Master of my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Then you don't like the Colonel so well as I thought you did, Madam, or you would not take such a Resolution.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: It is because I do like him, Betty, that I take such a Resolution.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Why, do you expect, Madam, the Colonel can work Miracles? Is it possible for him to marry you with the Consent of all your Guardians?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: Or he must not marry me at all, and so I told him; and he did not seem displeas'd with the News.—He promis'd to set me free, and I, on the Condition, promis'd to make him Master of that Freedom.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Well! I have read of inchanted Castles, Ladies delivered from the Chains of Magick, Giants kill'd, and Monsters overcome; so that I shall be the less surpriz'd, if the Colonel should conjure your
out

head.hi: A Bold Stroke For A Wife.

sp.l: out of the Power of your Guardians: If he does, I am sure he deserves your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: And shall have it, Girl, if it were ten times as much—For I'll ingenuously confess to thee, that I do like the Colonel above all Men I ever saw—There's something so Jantée in a Soldier, a kind of a Je ne scay quoi Air, that makes 'em more agreeable than the rest of Mankind—They command Regard, as who should say, We are your Defenders, We preserve your Beauties from the Insults of rude unpolish'd Foes, and ought to be preferr'd before those lazy indolent Mortals, who by dropping into their Fathers Estate set up their Coaches, and think to rattle themselves into our Affections.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, I confess that the Army has engross'd all the prettiest Fellows—A lac'd Coat and Feather have irresistable Charms.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: But the Colonel has all the Beauties of the Mind, as well as Person.—O all ye Powers, that favour happy Lovers, grant he may be mine! Thou God of Love, if thou be'st ought but Name, assist my Fainwell.

l.hi: Point all thy Darts to aid my Love's Design,
And make his Plots as prevalent as thine.

div.trailer: The End of the First ACT.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

div.head: SCENE 1.
div.stage: Enter Colonel finely drest, three Footmen after him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: SO, now if I can but meet this Beau—'Egad, methinks I cut a smart Figure, and have as much of the tawdry Air, as any Italian Count, or French Marquée of 'em all—Sure I shall know this Knight again,—ah! yonder he sits, making Love to a Mask, i'faith, I'll walk up the Mall, and come down by him.

div.stage: SCENE draws, and discovers Sir Philip upon a Bench with a Woman mask'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Well, but, my Dear, are you really constant to your Keeper?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Yes, really, Sir—hey day! who comes yonder, he cuts a mighty Figure.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Ha! A Stranger, by his Equipage keeping so close at his Heels—He has the Appearance of a Man of Quality—Positively, French by his dancing Air.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: He crosses, as if he meant to sit down here.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: He has a mind to make love to thee, Child.—

div.stage: Enter Colonel, and seats himself upon the Bench by Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: It will be to no Purpose if he does.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Are you resolv'd to be cruel then?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You must be very cruel, indeed, if you can deny any thing to so fine a Gentleman, Madam. [Takes out his Watch.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I never mind the Outside of a Man.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And I'm afraid thou art no Judge of the Inside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: I am positively of your Mind, Sir. For Creatures of her Function seldom penetrate beyond the Pocket.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Creatures of your Composition have, indeed, generally more in their Pockets than in their Heads. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Pray what says your Watch? mine is down. [Pulling out his Watch.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I want 36 Minutes of Twelve, Sir— [Puts up his Watch, and takes out his Snuff-Box.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: May I presume, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Sir, you honour me. [Presenting the Box.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: He speaks good English— tho' he must be a Foreigner;—this Snuff is extreamly good—and the Box prodigious fine; the Work is French I presume, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I bought it in Paris, Sir,—I do think the Workmanship pretty neat.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Neat! 'tis exquisitely fine, Sir; pray, Sir, if I may take the Liberty of inquiring—what Country is so happy to claim the Birth of the finest Gentleman in the Universe? France, I presume.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Then you don't think me an Englishman?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: No, upon my Soul don't I.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am sorry for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l:
Impossible you should wish to be an
Englishman—
Pardon me, Sir, this Island could not produce a Person of such Alertness.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
As this Mirrour shews you, Sir.
[Puts up a Pocket-Glass to Sir Philip's Face.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Coxcombs! I'm sick to hear 'em praise one another; one seldom gets any thing by such Animals, not even a Dinner, unless one can dine upon Soop and Sallery.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: O Ged, Sir! Will you leave us, Madam? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: She fears 'twill be only losing Time to stay here, ha, ha,—I know not how to distinguish you,
Sir,

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.l:
Sir, but your Mien and Address speak you
Right Honourable.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Thus great Souls judge of others by themselves—I am only adorn'd with Knighthood, that's all I assure you, Sir, my Name is Sir Philip Modelove.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Of French Extraction?—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: My Father was French.

sp.speaker: Col.
Sir Phil.
sp.l: I must own, I had the Offer of a Barony about five Years ago, but I abhorr'd the Fatigue which must have attended it—I could never yet bring my self to join with either Party.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You are perfectly in the right, Sir Philip— a fine Person should not embark himself in the slovenly Concern of Politicks; Dress and Pleasure are Objects proper for the Soul of a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: And Love—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Oh! that's included under the Article of Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Parbleu, il est un homme d'esprit, I must embrace you— [Rises and embraces.] Your Sentiments are so agreeable to mine, that we appear to have but one Soul, for our Ideas and Conceptions are the same.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I should be sorry for that [aside.] You do me too much Honour, Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Your Vivacity and Jantée Mien assured me at first sight there was nothing of this foggy Island in your Composition. May I crave your Name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My Name is La Fainwell, Sir, at you Service.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: The La Fainwells are French, I know; tho' the Name is become very numerous in Great Britain of late Years.—I was sure you was French the Moment I laid my Eyes upon you; I could not come in to the Supposition of your being an Englishman, this Island produces few such Ornaments.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir Philip, this Island has two things superior to all Nations under the Sun.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Ay! what are they?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The Ladies, and the Laws.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: The Laws indeed do claim a Preference of other Nations,—but by my Soul there are fine Women every where—I must own I have felt their Power in all Countries.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There are some finish'd Beauties, I confess, in France, Italy, Germany, nay, even in Holland; mais sont bien rare: But les belles Angloises!— Oh, Sir Philip, where find we such Women! such Symetry of Shape! such Elegancy of Dress! such Regularity of Features! such Sweetness of Temper! such commanding Eyes! and such bewitching Smiles?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Ah! parbleu vous estéz attrapér.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Non, je vous assure, Chevalier— but I declare there is no Amusement so agreeable to my Goût, as the Conversation of a fine Woman—I could never be prevail'd upon to enter into what the Vulgar calls the Pleasure of the Bottle.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: My own Taste, positivement— A Ball, or a Masquerade, is certainly preferable to all the Productions of the Vineyard.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Infinitely! I hope the People of Quality in
England
will support that Branch of Pleasure, which was imported with their Peace, and since naturaliz'd by the ingenious Mr. Heidegger.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: The Ladies assure me it will become Part of the Constitution,—upon which I subscrib'd a hundred Guineas—it will be of great Service to the Publick, at least to the Company of Surgeons, and the City in general.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ha, ha, it may help to ennoble the Blood of the City. Are you married, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: No, nor do I believe I ever shall enter into that honourable State; I have an absolute Tender for the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That's more than they have for you, I dare swear. [Aside.

div.p: B

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: And I have the Honour to be very well with the Ladies, I can assure you, Sir; and I won't affront a Million of fine Women, to make one happy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Nay, Marriage is really reducing a Man's Taste to a kind of half Pleasure, but then it carries the Blessing of Peace along with it, one goes to sleep without Fear, and wakes without Pain.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: There's something of that in't; a Wife is a very good Dish for an English Stomach—but gross Feeding for nicer Palates, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I find I was very much mistaken,—I imagin'd, you had been married to that young Lady which I saw in the Chariot with you this Morning in Grace-church-street.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Who, Nancy Lovely? I am a Piece of a Guardian to that Lady, you must know; her Father, I thank him, join'd me with three of the most preposterous old Fellows—that upon my Soul I'm in pain for the poor Girl,—she must certainly lead Apes, as the Saying is; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
Sir Phil.
sp.l: As to the Lady, she'd gladly be rid of us at any Rate, I believe; but here's the Mischief, he who marries Miss Lovely, must have the Consent of us all four,—or not a Penny of her Portion.—For my Part, I shall never approve of any, but a Man of Figure,—and the rest are not only averse to Cleanliness, but have each a peculiar Taste to gratify.—For my Part, I declare, I would prefer you to all Men I ever saw.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And I her to all Women—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: I assure you, Mr. Fainwell, I am for marrying her, for I hate the Trouble of a Guardian, especially among such Wretches; but resolve never to agree to the Choice of any one of them,—and I fancy they'll be even with me, for they never came into any Proposal of mine yet.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I wish I had your Leave to try them, Sir Philip.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: With all my Soul, Sir. I can refuse a Person of your Appearance nothing.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Sir, I am infinitely oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: But do you really like Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I believe I could with that Lady, Sir,

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: The only Point in which we differ—but you are Master of so many Qualifications, that I can excuse one Fault, for I must think it a Fault in a fine Gentleman; and that you are such, I'll give it under my hand.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I wish you'd give me your Consent to marry Mrs. Lovely under your Hand, Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: I'll do'r, if you'll step into St. James's Coffee-House, where we may have Pen and Ink—tho' I can't foresee what Advantage my Consent will be to you, without you could find a way to get the rest of the Guardians—but I'll introduce you however, she is now at a Quaker's where I carried her this Morning, when you saw us in Grace-church-street.— I assure you she has an odd Ragoût of Guardians, as you will find when you hear the Characters, which I'll endeavour to give you as we go along—Hey! Pierre, Jaque, Renno— where are you all, Scoundrels?—Order the Chariot to St. James's Coffee-House.

l.hi: Le Noir, la Brun, le Blanc—Mortblu, ou sont ces Coquins-la? Alons, Monsieur le Chevalier.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Ah! Pardonnez moy, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Not one Step upon my Soul, Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: The best-bred Man in Europe, positively.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Lovely, follow'd by Mrs. Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Then thou wilt not obey me; and thou do'st really think those Fallals becometh thee?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I do, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Now will I be judged by all sober People, if I don't look more like a modest Woman than thou dost, Anne.

div.p: B2

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: More like a Hypocrite you mean, Mrs. Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l:
Ah! Anne, Anne, that wicked
Philip Modelove
will undo thee— Satan so fills thy Heart with Pride, during the three Months of his Guardianship, that thou becomest a Stumbling-block to the Upright.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Pray who are they? Are the pinch'd Cap, and formal Hood, the Emblems of Sanctity? Does your Virtue consist in your Dress, Mrs. Prim?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: It doth not consist in cut Hair, spotted Face, and bare Necks,—Oh the Wickedness of this Generation! The Primitive Women knew not the Abomination of hoop'd Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: No, nor the Abomination of Cant neither. Don't tell me, Mrs. Prim, don't—I know you have as much Pride, Vanity, Self-conceit and Ambition among you, couch'd under that formal Habit, and sanctify'd Countenance, as the proudest of us all; but the World begins to see your Prudry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Prudry! What! do they invent new Words as well as new Fashions? Ah! poor fantastick Age, I pity thee—poor deluded Anne; Which dost thou think most resemblest the Saint, and which the Sinner, thy Dress, or mine? Thy naked Bosom allureth the Eye of the By-stander—encourageth the Frailty of Humane Nature—and corrupteth the Soul with evil Longings.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: And pray who corrupted your Son Tobias with evil Longings? Your Maid Tabitha wore a Handkerchief, and yet he made the Saint a Sinner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: No! that's plainly to be seen.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Tabitha is one of the Faithful, he fell not with a Stranger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: So! Then you hold Wenching no Crime, provided it be within the Pale of your own Tribe—you are an excellent Casuist truly.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Not stripp'd of thy Vanity yet, Anne! Why dost not thou make her put it off, Sarah?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: She will not do it.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Verily, thy naked Breasts troubleth my outward Man; I pray thee hide 'em, Anne; put on a Handkerchief, Anne Lovely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I hate Handkerchiefs when 'tis not cold Weather, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: I have seen thee wear a Handkerchief; nay, and a Mask to boot, in the middle of July.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Ay, to keep the Sun from scorching me.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: If thou cou'd'st not bear the Sun-beams, how dost thou think Man shou'd bear thy Beams? Those Breasts inflame Desire, let them be hid, I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Let me be quiet, I say:—Must I be tormented thus for ever? Sure no Woman's Condition ever equal'd mine; Foppery, Folly, Avarice and Hypocrisy, are by Turns my constant Companions,—and I must vary Shapes as often as a Player.—I cannot think my Father meant this Tyranny! No; you usurp an Authority which he never intended you shou'd take.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Hark thee, Do'st thou call good Counsel Tyranny? Do I, or my Wife, tyrannize, when we desire thee in all Love to put off thy Tempting Attire, and vail thy Provokers to Sin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Deliver me, good Heaven! or I shall go distracted. [Walks about.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: So! now thy Pinners are tost, and thy Breasts pull'd up;—verily they were seen enough
be-

div.p: B3

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.l: before;—fie upon the filthy Taylor who made them Stays.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I wish I were in my Grave! Kill me rather than treat me thus.—

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Kill thee! ha, ha; thou think'st thou art Acting some lude Play sure;—kill thee! Art thou prepar'd for Death, Anne Lovely? No, no, thou wou'dst rather have a Husband, Anne:— Thou wantest a Gilt Coach, with six lazy Fellows behind, to flant it in the Ring of Vanity—among the Princes and Rulers of the Land,—who pamper themselves with the Fatness thereof; but I will take care that none shall squander away thy Father's Estate; thou shalt marry none such, Anne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Wou'd you marry me to one of your own Canting Sex?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Yea, verily, no ne else shall ever get my Consent, I do assure thee, Anne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: And I do assure thee, Obadiah, that I will as soon turn Papist, and dye in a Convent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Oh Wickedness!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Oh Stupidity!

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Oh Blindness of Heart!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l:
Thou Blinder of the World, don't provoke me—lest I betray your Sanctity, and leave your Wife to judge of your Purity:—What were the Emotions of your Spirit,—when you squeez'd
Mary
by the Hand last Night in the Pantry,—when she told you, you buss'd so filthily? Ah! you had no Aversion to naked Bosoms, when you begg'd her to show you a little, little, little Bit of her delicious Bubby:—don't you remember those Words, Mr. Prim?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: What does she say, Obadiah?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: She talketh unintelligibly, Sarah. Which Way did she hear this? This shou'd not have reach'd the Ears of the wicked ones;—verily, it troubleth me, [Aside.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Philip Modelove, whom they call Sir Philip, is below, and such another with him, shall I send them up?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Yea.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: How do'st thou do, Friend Prim; odso! my She-Friend here too! What, you are documenting Miss Nancy, reading her a Lecture upon the pinch'd Coif, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: I am sure thou never readest her any Lecture that was good.—My Flesh riseth so at these wicked Ones, that Prudence adviseth me to withdraw from their Sight.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Oh! that I cou'd find Means to speak to her! How charming she appears! I wish I cou'd get this Letter into her Hand. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Well, Miss Cockey, I hope thou hast got the better of them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: The Difficulties of my Life are not to be surmounted, Sir Philip,— I hate the Impertinence of him, as much as the Stupidity of the other. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Prim.
sp.l: Verily, Philip, thou wilt spoil this Maiden.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: I find we still differ in Opinion; but that we may none of us spoil her, pr'ythee, Prim, let us consent to marry her—I have sent for our Brother Guardians to meet me here about that very Thing.—Madam, will you give me Leave to recommend a Husband to you.—Here's a Gentleman, which, in my Mind, you can have no Objection to.

div.stage: [Presents the Colonel to her, she looks another Way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Heaven deliver me from the Formal, and the Fantastick Fool. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A fine Woman,—a fine Horse, and fine Equipage, are the finest Things in the Universe:—And if I am so happy to possess you, Madam, I shall become

div.p: B4

sp.l: the

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.l:
the Envy of Mankind, as much as you out-shine your whole Sex.
[As he takes her Hand to kiss it, he endeavours to put the Letter into it, she lets it drop, —Prim takes it up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I have no Ambition to appear conspicuously ridiculous, Sir. [Turning from him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: So fall the Hopes of Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Ha! Fainwell! 'tis he! What have I done? Prim has the Letter, and all will be discover'd. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Friend, I know not thy Name, so cannot call thee by it; but thou seest thy Letter is unwelcome to the Maiden, she will not read it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Nor shall you; [Snatches the Letter] I'll tear it in a thousand Pieces, and scatter it, as I will the Hopes of all those that any of you shall recommend to me. [Tears the Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Ha! Right Woman, faith!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Excellent Woman. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Friend, thy Garb savoureth too much of the Vanity of the Age for my Approbation; nothing that resembleth Philip Modelove shall I love, mark that;—therefore, Friend Philip, bring no more of thy own Apes under my Roof.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: I am so entirely a Stranger to the Monsters of thy Breed, that I shall bring none of them, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am likely to have a pretty Task by that time I have gone thro' them all; but she's a City worth taking, and 'egad I'll carry on the Siege: If I can but blow up the Out-works, I fancy I am pretty secure of the Town. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l:
Toby Periwinkle and Thomas Tradelove demandeth to see thee.
[To Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Bid them come up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Deliver me from such an Inundation of Noise and Nonsense. Oh Fainwell! whatever thy Contrivance

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.l: is, prosper it Heaven;—but oh! I fear thou never canst redeem me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.

l.hi: Sic transit Gloria Mundi!

sp.l:
These are my Brother Guardians, Mr. Fainwell; pr'ythee observe the Creatures.
[Aside to the Col.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.l: Well, Sir Philip, I obey your Summons.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray, what have you to offer for the Good of Mrs. Lovely, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: First I desire to know what you intend to do with that Lady? Must she be sent to the Indies for a Venture,—or live to be an old Maid, and then enter'd amongst your Curiosities, and shewn for a Monster, Mr. Periwinkle?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Humph, Curiosities! that must be the Virtuoso. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why, what wou'd you do with her?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: I wou'd recommend this Gentleman to her for a Husband, Sir—a Person whom I have pick'd out from the whole Race of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: I wou'd advise thee to shuffle him again with the rest of Mankind, for I like him not.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, without Offence to your Formality, what may be your Objections?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Thy Person; thy Manners; thy Dress; thy Acquaintance;—thy every Thing, Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: You are most particularly obliging, Friend, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.l: What Business do you follow, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Humph, by that Question he must be the Broker. [Aside.] —Business, Sir! the Business of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.l: That is as much as to say, you dress fine, feed high, lie with every Woman you like, and pay your Surgeon's Bills better than your Taylors or your Butchers.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The Court is much oblig'd to you, Sir, for your Character of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.l: The Court, Sir! What wou'd the Court do without us Citizens?

div.p: B5

head.hi: A Bold Stroke For a Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Without your Wives and Daughters you mean, Mr. Tradelove?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Have you ever travell'd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That Question must not be answer'd now—In Books I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: In Books? That's fine travelling indeed!—Sir Philip, when you present a Person I like, he shall have my Consent to marry Mrs. Lovely, 'till when, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I'll make you like me before I have done with you, or I am mistaken. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.l: And when you can convince me, that a Beau is more useful to my Country than a Merchant, you shall have mine: 'till then you must excuse me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: So much for Trade,—I'll fit you too. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: In my Opinion, this is very inhumane Treatment, as to the Lady, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Thy Opinion and mine happens to differ as much as our Occupations, Friend; Business requireth my Presence, and Folly thine, and so I must bid thee farewel.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Here's Breeding for you, Mr. Fainwel!— Gad take me, I'd give half my Estate to see these Rascals bit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I hope to bite you all, if my Plots hit. [Aside.

div.head: SCENE I. SCENE the Tavern;
div.stage: SCENE the Tavern; Sackbut, and the Colonel in an Ægyptian Dress.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: A Lucky Beginning, Colonel—you have got the old Beau's Consent.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ay, he's a reasonable Creature; but the other three will require some Pains—Shall I pass upon him, think you? Egad, in my Mind, I look as Antique as if I had been preserv'd in the Ark.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Pass upon him! ay, ay, as roundly as White-wine dash'd with Sack does for Mountain and Sherry, if you have but Assurance enough—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have no Apprehension from that Quarter; Assurance is the Cockade of a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Ay, but the Assurance of a Soldier differs much from that of a Traveller—Can you lye with a good Grace?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: As heartily when my Mistress is the Prize, as I would meet the Foe when my Country call'd, and King commanded; so don't you fear that Part; if he don't know me again I'm sase—I hope he'll come.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: I wish all my Debts would come as sure. I told him you had been a great Traveller, had many valuable Curiosities, and was a Person of a most singular Taste; he seem'd transported, and begg'd me to keep you till he came.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.l: Ay, ay, he need not fear my running away—Let's have a Bottle of Sack, Landlord, our Ancestors drank Sack.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: You shall have it.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And where-abouts is the Trap-door you mentioned?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: There's the Conveyance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Now if I should cheat all these Roguish Guardians, and carry off my Mistress in Triumph, it would be what the French call a Grand Coup d'Eclat— Odso! here comes Periwinkle— Ah! duce take this Beard, pray Jupiter it does not give me the slip, and spoil all.

div.stage: Enter Sackbut with Wine, and Periwinkle following.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Sir, this Gentleman hearing you have been a great Traveller, and a Person of fine Speculation, begs leave to take a Glass with you; he is a Man of a curious Taste himself.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The Gentleman has it in his Face and Garb: Sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir, I honour a Traveller, and Men of your enquiring Disposition; the Oddness of your Habit pleases me extreamly; 'tis very Antique, and for that I like it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Tis very Antique, Sir;—This Habit once belong'd to the famous Claudius Ptolomeus, who liv'd in the Year a Hundred and Thirty Five.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: If he keeps up to the Sample, he shall lye with the Devil for a Bean-Stack, and win it every Straw. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A Hundred and Thirty Five! why, that's prodigious now—Well, certainly 'tis the finest thing in the World to be a Traveller.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: For my part I value none of the modern Fashions of a Fig-Leaf.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No more do I, Sir; I had rather be the Jest of a Fool, than his Favourite,—I am laugh'd at her for my Singularity—This Coat you must know, Sir, was formerly worn by that Ingenious and very Learned Person, John Tradescant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: John Tradescant! Let me embrace you, Sir— John Tradescant was my Uncle, by Mother-side; and
I

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.l: I thank you for the Honour you do his Memory; he was a very curious Man indeed.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Your Uncle, Sir,—Nay then, 'tis no wonder that your Taste is so refin'd; why, you have it in your Blood—My humble Service to you, Sir, to the immortal Memory of John Tradescant, your never-to-be-forgotten Uncle. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Give me a Glass, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Per.
Sack.
sp.l: Oh Pox! that would have spoil'd the Jest. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A Person of your Curiosity must have collected many Rarities.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have some, Sir, which are not yet come ashore, as an Egyptian Idol.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray what might that be?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: It is, Sir, a Kind of an Ape, which they formerly worshipp'd in that Country; I took it from the Breast of a Female Mummy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ha, ha! our Women retain part of their Idolatry to this Day, for many an Ape lies on a Lady's Breast, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: A smart old Thief. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Two Tusks of an Hippotamus, two Pair of Chinese Nut-crackers, and one Egyptian Mummy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray, Sir have you never a Crocodile?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Humph! the Boatswain brought one with Design to shew it, but touching at Rotterdam, and hearing it was no Rarity in England, he sold it to a Dutch Poet.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: The Devil's in that Nation, it rivals us in every thing.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I should have been very glad to have seen a living Crocodile.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
Per.
sp.l: To Cinders? You amaze me Sir; I never heard that the Sun consum'd any thing— Descartes tells us—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Descartes, with the rest of his Brethren both ancient and modern, knew nothing of the Matter—I tell you Sir, that Nature admits an annual Decay, tho' imperceptible to vulgar Eyes—Sometimes his Rays destroy below, sometimes above—You have heard of Blazing Comets, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I remember to have seen one; and our Astrologers tell us of another which shall happen very quickly.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Those Comets are little Islands bordering on the Sun, which at certain Times are set on Fire by that Luminous Body's moving over them perpendicular, which will one Day occasion a general Conflagration.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: One need not scruple the Colonel's Capacity, Faith [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: This is marvellous strange! These Cinders are what I never read of in any of our Learned Dissertations.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I don't know how the Devil you should. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: He has at this Fingers Ends; one would swear he had learned to lye at School, he does it so cleverly. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well! you Travellers see strange things! Pray, Sir, have you any of those Cinders?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have, among my other Curiosities.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Oh, what have I lost for want of Travelling!—Pray what have you else?

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Several Things worth your Attention—I have a Muff made of the Feathers of those Geese that sav'd the Roman Capitol.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Yes, if you are such a Goose to believe him. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have an Indian Leaf which open, will cover an Acre of Land, yet folds up in so little a Compass, you may put it into your Snuff-Box.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Humph! that's a Thunderer. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Amazing!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ah! mine is but a little one; I have seen some of them that would cover one of the Carribian Islands.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, if I don't travel before I die, I sha'nt rest in my Grave—Pray, what do the Indians with them?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Sir, they use them in their Wars for Tents, the Old Women for Ridinghoods, the Young for Fans and Umbrellas.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: He has a fruitful Invention. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I admire our East-India Company imports none of them, they would certainly find their Account in them.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Right, if they could find the Leaves. [Aside.
—Look ye, Sir, do you see this little Vial?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray you, what is it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: This is called Poluflosboio.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Poluflosboio!— it has a rumbling Sound.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Right, Sir. it proceeds from a rumbling Nature—This Water was part of those Waves, which bore Cleopatra's Vessel when she sail'd to meet Anthony.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, of all that ever travell'd, none had a Taste like you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: But here's the Wonder of the World—This, Sir, is called Zona, or Moros Musphonon, the Virtues of this is inestimable.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Moros Musphonon! What, in the Name of Wisdom, can that be?—to me it seems a plain Belt.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: This Girdle has carried me all the World over.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You have carried it, you mean.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I mean as I say, Sir—Whenever I am girded with this, I am invisible; and by turning this little Screw, can be in the Court of the Great Mogul, the Grand Seignior, and King George, in as little Time as your Cook can poach an Egg.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You must pardon me, Sir, I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: If my Landlord pleases, he shall try the Experiment immediately.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: I thank you kindly, Sir, but I have no Inclination to ride Post to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No, no, you shan't stir a Foot, I'll only make you invisible.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: But if you could not make me visible again.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Come try it upon me, Sir, I am not afraid of the Devil, nor all his Tricks.—Zbud, I'll stand 'em all.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There, Sir, put it on—Come, Landlord, you and I must face the East. [They turn about.] Is it on, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis on. [They turn about again.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Heaven protect me! where is he?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why here, just where I was.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Where, where, in the Name of Virtue? Ah, poor Mr. Periwinkle!— Egad look to't, you had best, Sir, and let him be seen again, or I shall have you burnt for a Wizzard.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Have Patience, good Landlord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: But really don't you see me now?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: No more than I see my Grandmother that dy'd forty Years ago.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Are you sure you don't lye? Methinks I stand just where I did, and see you as plain as I did before.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Ah! I wish I could see you once again.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Take off the Girdle, Sir. [He takes it off.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Ah, Sir, I am glad to see you with all my Heart. [Embraces him.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: This is very odd; certainly there must be some Trick in't—Pray, Sir, will you do me the Favour to put it on your self.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: But first I'll secure the Door.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
You know how to turn the Screw, Mr.
Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l:
Yes, yes—Come Mr. Periwinkle, we must turn full East.
[They turn, the Colonel sinks down a Trap-door.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Tis done, now turn. [They turn.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ha! Mercy upon me! My Flesh creeps upon my Bones—This must be a Conjurer, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: He is the Devil, I think.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Oh! Mr. Sackbut, why do you name the Devil, when perhaps he may be at your Elbow.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: At my Elbow! marry, Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Are you satisfied, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, yes—How hollow his Voice sounds!

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l:
Yours seem'd just the same—Faith, I wish this Girdle were mine, I'd sell Wine no more. Hark ye, Mr. Periwinkle,
[Takes him aside till the Colonel rises again.]
if he would sell this Girdle, you might travel with great Expedition.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: But it is not to be parted with for Money.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am sorry for't, Sir, because I think it the greatest Curiosity I ever heard of.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: By the Advice of a learned Phisiognomist in Grand Cairo, who consulted the Lines in my Face, I returned to England, where, he told me, I should find a Rarity in the Keeping of four Men, which I was born to possess for the Benefit of Mankind, and the first of the four that gave me his Consent, I should present him with this Girdle—Till I have found this Jewel, I shall not part with the Girdle.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What can that Rarity be? Did he not name it to you?

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Yes, Sir; he call'd it a Chaste, Beautiful, Unaffected Woman.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pish! Women are no Rarities.—I never had any great Taste that Way. I married, indeed, to please a Father, and I got a Girl to please my Wife; but she and the Child (thank Heaven) died together—Women are the very Gewgaws of the Creation; Play-things for Boys, which, when they write Man, they ought to throw aside.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: A fine Lecture to be read to a Circle of Ladies! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What Woman is there, drest in all the Pride and Foppery of the Times, can boast of such a Foretop as the Cockatoor.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I must humour him. [Aside.] Such a Skin as the Lizzard?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Such a shining Breast as the Humming-Bird?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Such a Shape as the Antilope?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Or, in all the artful Mixture of their various Dresses, have they half the Beauty of one Box of Butterflies?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No, that must be allow'd—For my part, if it were not for the Benefit of Mankind, I'd have nothing to do with them, for they are as indifferent to me, as a Sparrow or a Flesh-Fly.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, what Benefit is the World to reap from this Lady?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why, Sir, she is to bear me a Son, who shall restore the Art of Embalming, and the old Roman Manner of Burying their Dead; and, for the Benefit of Posterity, he is to discover the Longitude, so long sought for in vain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l:
Od! these are very valuable Things, Mr.
Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: He hits it off admirably, and t'other swallows it like Sack and Sugar. [Aside.] Certainly this Lady must be your Ward, Mr. Periwinkle, by her being under the Care of four Persons.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By the Description it should—Egad, if I could get that Girdle, I'd ride with the Sun, and make the Tour of the whole World in four and twenty Hours [Aside.] And are you to give that Girdle to the first of the four Guardiar s that shall give his Consent to marry that Lady, say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am so order'd, when I can find him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I fancy I know the very Woman—her Name is Ann Lovely.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Excellent!—he said, indeed, that the first Letter of her Name was L.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Did he really?—Well, that's prodigiously amazing, that a Person in Grand Cairo should know any thing of my Ward.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Your Ward?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: To be plain with you, Sir, I am one of those four Guardians.

sp.speaker: Col,
sp.l: Are you indeed, Sir? I am transported to find the Man who is to possess this Moros Musphonon is a Person of so curious a Taste—Here is a Writing drawn up by that famous Egyptian, which, if you will please to sign, you must turn your Face full North, and the Girdle is yours.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: If I live till this Boy is born, I'll be embalm'd and sent to the Royal Society when I die.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That you shall most certainly.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Here's Mr. Staytape the Taylor, enquires for you, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Who do you speak to, you Son of a Whore?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ha! Colonel! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Confound the blundering Dog! [Aside

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Why, to Colonel—

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l:
Get you out you Rascal.
[Kicks him out, and Exit after him.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: What the Devil is the Matter?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
This Dog has ruin'd all my Scheme, I see by
Periwinkle 's Looks. [Aside.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How finely I should have been chous'd— Colonel, you'll pardon me that I did not give your Title before—it was pure Ignorance, Faith it was—Pray—hem, hem—Pray, Colonel, what Post had this Learned Egyptian in your Regiment?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A Pox of your Snear [Aside.] I don't understand you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No? that's strange! I understand you, Colonel— An Egyptian of Grand Cario! ha, ha, ha—I am sorry such a well-invented Tale should do you no more Service—We old Fellows can see as far into a Mill-stone, as him that picks it—I am not to be trick'd out of my Trust—mark that.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The Devil! I must carry it off; I wish I were fairly out. [Aside.] Look ye, Sir, you may make what Jest you please—but the Stars will be obey'd, Sir, and, depend upon it, I shall have the Lady, and you none of the Girdle—Now for Freeman's Part of the Plot. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l:
The Stars! ha, ha—No Star has favour'd you, it seems—The Girdle! ha, ha, ha, none of your Lagerdemain's Tricks can pass upon me—Why, what a Pack of Trumpery has this Rogue pick'd up?—His Pagod, Poluflosboios, his Zonas, Moros Musphonons, and the Devil knows what—But I'll take Care—Ha gone?—Ay, 'twas time to sneak off—Soho! the House!
[Enter Sackbut.]
Where is this Trickster? Send for a Constable, I'll have this Rascal before the Lord Mayor; I'll Grand Cairo him, with a Pox to him—I believe you had a Hand in putting this Imposture upon me,
Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l:
Who I, Mr. Periwinkle? I scorn it; I perceiv'd he was a Cheat, and left the Room on purpose to send for a Constable to apprehend him, and endeavour'd to stop him when he went out—but the Rogue made but one Step from the Stairs to the Door, call'd a Coach, leapt into it, and drove away like the Devil, as Mr.
Freeman
can witness, who is at the Bar, and desires to speak with you; he is this Minute come to Town.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l:
Send him in.
[Exit Sackbut.]
What a Scheme this Rogue had laid! How I should have been laugh'd at, had it succeeded!
[Enter Freeman Booted and Spurr'd.]
Mr. Freeman, your Dress commands your Welcome to Town; what will you drink? I had like to have been impos'd upon here by the veriest Rascal—

sp.speaker: Free.
Per.
sp.l: I believe you never heard of such a Contrivance, Mr. Freeman, as this Fellow had found out.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Mr. Sackbut has told me the whole Story, Mr. Periwinkle; but now I have something to tell you of much more Importance to your self—I happen'd to lie one Night at Coventry, and knowing your Uncle Sir Toby Periwinkle, I paid him a Visit, and to my great Surprize found him dying.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Dying!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Dying, in all Appearance; the Servants weeping, the Room in Darkness; the Apothecary shaking his Head, told me, the Doctors had given him over; and then there is small Hopes, you know.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I hope he has made his Will—he always told me, he wou'd make me his Heir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I have heard you say as much, and therefore resolv'd to give you Notice. I should think, it would not be amiss if you went down to-morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It is a long Journey, and the Roads very bad.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: But he has a great Estate, and the Land very good—Think upon that.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why that's true, as you say; I'll think upon it: In the mean time I give you many Thanks for your Civility, Mr. Freeman, and should be glad of your Company to dine with me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I am oblig'd to be at Jonathan's Coffee-House at Two, and it is now half an Hour after One; if I
dis-

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.l: dispatch my Business, I'll wait on you; I know your Hour.

sp.speaker: Per.
Free.
Col.
sp.l: I overheard all, tho' I am a little in the dark: I am to personate a Highway-Man, I suppose—That's a Project I am not fond of; for tho' I may fright him out of his Consent, he may fright me out of my Life when he discovers me, as he certainly must in the End.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: No, no, I have a Plot for you without Danger; but first we must manage Tradelove—Has the Taylor brought your Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Yes, Pox take the Thief.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Pox take your Drawer, for a jolt-headed Rogue.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Well, well, no matter, I warrant we have him yet—But now you must put on the Dutch Merchant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The Duce of this Trading-Plot—I wish he had been an old Soldier, that I might have attack'd him in my own Way, heard him fight over all the Battles of the Civil War—but for Trade, by Jupiter I shall never do it.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Never fear, Colonel, Mr. Freeman will instruct you.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You'll see what others do, the Coffee-house will instruct you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I must venture, however—But I have a farther Plot in my Head upon Tradelove, which you must assist me in Freeman; you are in Credit with him, I heard you say.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
I am, and will scruple nothing to serve you,
Colonel.

div.head: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Come along then—Now for the Dutchman—Honest Ptolomy, by your Leave,

l.hi: Now must Bob-Wig and Business come in Play,
And a fair Thirty Thousand Pounder leads the Way.

div.head: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.
ACT IV.

SCENE I.
SCENE,
Jonathan's Coffee-House in Exchange-Alley. Crowd of People with Rolls of Paper and Parchment in their Hands; a Bar, and Coffee-Boys waiting.
div.stage: Enter Tradelove, and Stockjobbers with Rolls of Paper and Parchment.

sp.speaker: 1st Stock.
sp.l: SOuth-Sea at seven Eights! who buys?

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.l:
South Sea Bonds due at
Michaelmas,
1718. Class-Lottery Tickets.

sp.speaker: 3d Stock.
sp.l: East India Bonds?

sp.speaker: 4th Stock.
sp.l: What all Sellers and no Buyers? Gentlemen, I'll buy a thousand Pound for Tuesday next at 3 Fourths.

sp.speaker: Coff. B.
sp.l: Fresh Coffee, Gentlemen, fresh Coffee?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Hark ye, Gabriel, you'll pay the Difference of that Stock we transacted for t'other Day.

sp.speaker: Gabr.
sp.l: Ay, Mr. Tradelove, here's a Note for the Money, upon the Sword-Blade Company. [Gives him a Note.

sp.speaker: Coff. B.
sp.l: Bohea-Tea, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is Mr. Smuggle here?

sp.speaker: 1st Coff. B.
sp.l: Mr. Smuggle's not here, Sir, you'll find him at the Books.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.l: Ho! here come two Sparks from the other End of the Town; what News bring they?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: I would fain Bite that Spark in the brown Coat, he comes very often into the Alley, but never employs a Broker.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.l: Who does any thing in the Civil List Lottery? or Caco? Zounds, where are all the Jews this Afternoon? Are you a Bull or a Bear to day, Abraham?

sp.speaker: 3d Stock.
sp.l: A Bull, faith,—but I have a good Putt for next Week.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Mr. Freeman your Servant! Who is that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: A Dutch Merchant, just come to England; but hark yee, Mr. Tradelove,— I have a Piece of News will get you as much as the French King's Death did, if you are expeditious.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Say you so, Sir! Pray, what is it?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: [Showing him a Letter.] Read there, I receiv'd it just now from one that belongs to the Emperor's Minister.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: [Reads.] Sir, As I have many Obligations to you, I cannot miss any Opportunity to show my Gratitude; this Moment my Lord has receiv'd a private Express, that the Spaniards have rais'd their Siege from before Cagliari; if this prove any Advantage to you, it will answer both the Ends and Wishes of, Sir, Your most obliged humble Servant, Henricus Dusseldorp.
Postscript. In two or three Hours the News will be publick.

May one depend upon this, Mr. Freeman?
[Aside to Freeman.]

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You may—I never knew this Person send me a false Piece of News in my Life.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Sir, I am much oblig'd to you, 'Egad 'tis rare News.—Who sells South Sea for next Week?

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.l: Job. [All together.] I sell; I, I, I, I, I sell.

sp.speaker: 1st Stock.
sp.l: I'll sell 5000 l. for next Week, at five Eighths.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.l: —I'll sell ten thousand at five Eighths for the same time.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Nay, nay, hold, hold, not all together, Gentlemen, I'll be no Bull, I'll buy no more than I can take:

div.p: C

sp.l: Wll

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.l: Will you sell ten thousand Pound at a half, for any Day next Week, except Saturday?

sp.speaker: 1st Stock.
sp.l: I'll sell it you, Mr. Tradelove.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l:
[Aloud.] The Spaniards rais'd the Siege of
Cagliari!
I don't believe one Word of it.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.l: Rais'd the Siege! as much as you have rais'd the Monument.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Tis rais'd I assure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.l: What will you lay on't?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: What you please.

sp.speaker: 1st Gent.
sp.l: Why, I have a Brother upon the Spot, in the Emperor's Service; I am certain if there were any such Thing, I shou'd have had a Letter.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.l: How's this? The Siege of Cagliari rais'd;—I wish it may be true, 'twill make Business stir, and Stocks rise.

sp.speaker: 1st Stock.
sp.l: Tradelove's a cunning fat Bear; if this News proves true, I shall repent I sold him the five thousand Pounds.—Pray, Sir, what Assurance have you that the Siege is rais'd?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: There is come an Express to the Emperor's Minister.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.l: I'll know that presently.

sp.speaker: 1st Gent.
sp.l: Let it come where it will, I'll hold you fifty Pounds 'tis false.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.l: I'll lay you a Brace of Hundreds upon the same.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I'll take you.

sp.speaker: 4th Stock.
sp.l: 'Egad, I'll hold twenty Pieces 'tis not rais'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Done, with you too.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: I'll lay any Man a Brace of Thousands the Siege is rais'd.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
The Dutch Merchant is your Man to take in.
[Aside to Tradelove.]

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Does not he know the News?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Not a Syllable; if he did, he wou'd bet a Hundred thousand Pound as soon as one Penny;—
he's

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.l:
he's plaguy Rich, and a mighty Man at Wagers.
[To Tradelove.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Say you so—'Egad, I'll bite him if possible:—Are you from Holland, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ya, Mynheer?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Had you the News before you came away?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Wat believe you, Mynheer?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: What do I believe? Why, I believe that the Spaniards have actually rais'd the Siege of Cagliari.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Wat Duyvels Niews is dat? 'Tis niet waer, Mynheer,—'tis no true, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: 'Tis so true, Mynheer, that I'll lay you two thousand Pounds upon it—You are sure the Letter may be depended upon, Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
Do you think I would venture my Money if I were not sure of the Truth of it?
[Aside to Trade.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Two duysend Pond, Mynheer, 'tis gedaen—dis Gentleman sal hold de Gelt.
[Gives Freeman Money.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: With all my Heart,—this binds the Wager.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: You have certainly lost, Mynheer, the Siege is raised indeed.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ik gelove't niet, Mynheer Freeman, ik sal ye dubbled houden, if you please.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I am let into the Secret, therefore won't win your Money.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! I have snapt the Dutchman, faith, ha, ha! this is no ill Day's Work,—pray may I crave your Name, Mynheer?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Myn Naem, Mynheer! myn Naem is, Jan van Timtamtirelereletta Heer van Fainwell?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Zounds 'tis a damn'd long Name, I shall never remember it —Myn Heer van Tim, Tim, Tim,— What the Devil is it?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Oh! never heed, I know the Gentleman, and will pass my Word for twice the Sum.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: That's enough.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You'll hear of me sooner than you'll wish old Gentleman, I fancy. [aside.] You'll come to Sackbut's, Freeman. [Exit.

div.p: C2

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
Immediately.
[Aside to the Colonel.

sp.speaker: 1st Man.
sp.l: Humphrey Hump here?

sp.speaker: 2d Boy.
sp.l: Mr. Humprey Hump is not here; you'll find him upon the Dutch Walk.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Mr. Freeman, I give you many Thanks for your Kindness.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I fear you'll repent when you know all. [aside.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Will you dine with me?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I am engag'd at Sackbut's; adieu.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Sir, your humble Servant. Now I'll see what I can do upon Change with my News.

head.hi: SCENE the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! the old Fellow swallow'd the Bait as greedily as a Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have him, faith, ha, ha, ha—His two thousand Pounds secure—if he wou'd keep his Money, he must part with the Lady, ha, ha—What came of your two Friends? they perform'd their Part very well; you should have brought 'em to take a Glass with us.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: No matter, we'll drink a Bottle together another Time,—I did not care to bring them hither; there's no Necessity to trust them with the main Secret, you know, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Nay, that's right, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Joy, Joy, Colonel! the luckiest Accident in the World!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: This Letter does your Business.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: (Reads.) To Obediah Prim, Hosier, near the Building call'd the Monument, in London.

head.hi: A Bold Stroke for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Free.
Sack.
sp.l: Looking over the Letters our Post-Woman brought, as I always do, to see what Letters are directed to my House, (for she can't read you must know) I spy'd this to Prim, so paid for't among the rest; I have given the old Jade a Pint of Wine on purpose to delay Time, 'till you see if the Letter will be of any Service; then I'll seal it up again, and tell her I took it by Mistake;—I have read it, and fancy you'll like the Project—read, read, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: [Reads.] Friend Prim, there is arriv'd from Pensilvania, one Simon Pure, a Leader of the Faithful, who hath sojourn'd with us eleven Days, and hath been of great Comfort to the Brethren—He intendeth for the Quarterly Meeting in London; I have recommended him to thy House; I pray thee intreat him kindly, and let thy Wife cherish him, for he's of weakly Constitution—he will depart from us the third Day; which is all from thy Friend in the Faith, Aminadad Holdfast.
Ha, ha! Excellent! I understand you, Landlord, I am to personate this Simon Pure, am I not?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Don't you like the Hint?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Admirably well!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Tis the best Contrivance in the World, if the right Simon gets not there before you.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No, no, the Quakers never ride Post; he can't be here before to-morrow at soonest: Do you send and buy me a Quaker's Dress, Mr. Sackbutt; and suppose, Freeman, you should wait at the Bristol Coach, that if you see any such Person, you might contrive to give me Notice—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I will—the Country Dress and Boots, are they ready?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Yes, yes, every thing—Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
Bring 'em in then,—
[Exit Sack. ]
Thou must dispatch Periwinkle first,—remember his Uncle Sir Toby Periwinkle is an old Batchelor of seventy five,—that he has seven hundred a Year, most in Abbey-Land; that he was once in Love with your Mother, and shrewdly suspected by some to be your Father,—that you
have been thirty Years his Steward,—and ten Years his Gentleman—remember to improve these Hints.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Never fear, let me alone for that,—but what's the Steward's Name?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: His Name is Pillage.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Enough—
[Enter Sackbut with Clothes.]
Now for the Country Put— [Dresses.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Egad, Landlord, thou deservest to have the first Night's Lodging with the Lady for thy Fidelity;—What say you, Colonel, shall we settle a Club here, you'll make one?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Make one; I'll bring a Sett of honest Officers, that will spend their Money as freely to the King's Health, as they would their Blood in his Service.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: I thank you, Colonel. Here, here. [Bell rings.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: So now for my Boots. [Puts on Boots.] Shall I find you here, Freeman, when I come back?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Yes,—or I'll leave Word with Sackbut, where he may send for me—Have you the Writings? the Will,—and every thing?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: All, all!—

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Zounds! Mr. Freeman! yonder is Tradelove in the damned'st Passion in the World.—He swears you are in the House,—he says you told him you was to dine here.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I did so. Ha, ha, ha! he has found himself bit already.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The Devil! he must not see me in this Dress.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: I told him I expected you here, but you were not come yet.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Very well,—make you haste out,! Colonel, and let me alone to deal with him: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: In the King's-Head.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You remember what I told you?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ay, ay, very well. Landlord, let him know I am come in,—and now, Mr. Pillage, success attend you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Mr. Proteus rather.—
From changing Shape and imitating Jove,

l.hi: I draw the happy Omens of my Love.
I'm not the first young Brother of the Blade
Who made his Fortune in a Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Zounds! Mr. Tradelove, we're bit it seems.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Bit do you call it, Mr. Freeman? I am ruin'd,—Pox on your News.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Pox on the Rascal that sent it me.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Sent it you! Why Gabriel Skinstint has been at the Minister's, and spoke with him, and he has assur'd him 'tis every Syllable false; he receiv'd no such Express.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I know it: I this Minute parted with my Friend, who protested he never sent me any such Letter,—some roguish Stockjobber has done it on purpose to make me lose my Money, that's certain; I wish I knew who he was, I'd make him repent it—I have lost three hundred Pounds by it.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: What signifies your 300 l. to what I have lost? There's two thousand Pounds to that Dutchman with the cursed long Name, besides the Stock I bought; the Devil! I cou'd tear my Flesh,—I must never show my Face upon Change more,—for, by my Soul, I can't pay it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I am heartily sorry for't! What can I serve you in? Shall I speak to the Dutch Merchant, and try to get you Time for the Payment?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Time! 'Ad'sheart! I shall never be able to look up again.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I am very much concern'd that I was the Occasion, and wish I could be an Instrument of retrieving your Misfortune; for my own I value it not.—'Adso! a Thought comes into my Head, that well improv'd, may be of Service.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Ah! there's no Thought can be of any Service to me, without paying the Money, or running away.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: How do you know? What do you think of my proposing Mrs. Lovely to him? He is a single Man,—and I heard him say he had a mind to marry an English Woman—nay, more than that, he said somebody told him, you had a pretty Ward—he wish'd you had betted her instead of your Money.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Ay, but he'd be hang'd before he'd take her instead of the Money; the Dutch are too covetous for that; besides, he did not know that there were three more of us I suppose.

sp.speaker: Free.
