sp.l: So much the better; you may venture to give him your Consent, if he'll forgive you the Wager: It is not your Business to tell him, that your Consent will signifie nothing.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: That's right, as you say; but will he do it, think you?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I can't tell that; but I'll try what I can do with him—He has promis'd me to meet me here an Hour hence; I'll feel his Pulse, and let you know: If I find it feasible, I'll send for you; if not, you are at liberty to take what Measures you please.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: You must extol her Beauty, double her Portion, and tell him I have the entire Disposal of her, and that she can't marry without my Consent;—and that I am a covetous Rogue, and will never part with her without a Valuable Consideration.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ay, ay, let me alone for a Lye at a Pinch.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l:
Egad, if you can bring this to bear, Mr.
Freeman,
I'll make you whole again; I'll pay the Three Hundred Pounds you lost, with all my Soul.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Well, I'll use my best Endeavours—Where will you be?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: At Home; pray Heaven you prosper—If I were but the sole Trustee now, I should not fear it. Who the Devil would be a Guardian,

l.hi: If when Cash runs low, our Coffers t'enlarge,
We can't, like other Stocks, transfer our Charge?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha—he has it.

head.hi:
SCENE changes to
's House.

div.stage: Enter Periwinkle on one Side, and Footman on t'other.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.l: A Gentleman from Coventry enquires for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: From my Uncle, I warrant you, bring him up—This will save me the Trouble, as well as the Expences of a Journey.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Is your Name Periwinkle, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am sorry for the Message I bring—My old Master, whom I served these forty Years, claims the Sorrow due from a faithful Servant to an indulgent Master. [Weeps.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l:
By this I understand, Sir, my Uncle Sir
Toby Periwinkle
is dead.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: He is, Sir, and he has left you Heir to Seven Hundred a Year, in as good Abbey-Land as ever paid Peter-Pence to Rome— I wish you long to enjoy it, but my Tears will flow when I think of my Benefactor— [Weeps.] Ah! he was a good Man—he has not left many of his Fellows—the Poor laments him sorely.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I pray, Sir, what Office bore you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I was his Steward, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I have heard him mention you with much Respect; your Name is—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Pillage, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ay, Pillage! I do remember he call'd you Pillage— Pray, Mr. Pillage, when did my Uncle die?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Monday last, at Four in the Morning. About Two he signed this Will, and gave it into my Hands, and strictly charged me to leave Coventry the Moment he expir'd, and deliver it to you with what Speed I could; I have obey'd him, Sir, and there is the Will.
[Gives it to Per.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, I'll lodge it in the Commons.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: There are two Things which he forgot to insert, but charged me to tell you, that he desired you'd perform them as readily as if you had found them written in the Will, which is to remove his Corpse, and bury him by his Father in St. Paul Covent-Garden, and to give all his Servants Mourning.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That will be a considerable Charge; a Pox of all modern Fashions. [Aside.] Well! it shall be done, Mr. Pillage; I will agree with one of Death's Fashion-Mongers, call'd an Undertaker, to go down, and bring up the Body.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I hope, Sir, I shall have the Honour to serve you in the same Station I did your Worthy Uncle; I have not many Years to stay behind him, and would gladly spend them in the Family, where I was brought up— [Weeps.] He was a kind and tender Master to me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray don't grieve Mr. Pillage, you shall hold your Place, and every thing else which you held under my Uncle—You make me weep to see you so concern'd. [Weeps.] He liv'd to a good old Age—and we are all mortal.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: We are so, Sir, and therefore I must beg you to sign this Lease: You'll find Sir Toby has ta'en particular Notice of it in his Will—I could not get it time enough from the Lawyer, or he had sign'd it before he dy'd. [Gives him a Paper.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A Lease for what?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I rented a Hundred a Year of Sir Toby upon Lease, which Lease expires at Lady-Day next, and I desire to renew it for twenty Years—that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Let me see. [Looks over the Lease.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Matters go swimmingly, if nothing intervene. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Very well—Let's see what he says in his Will about it. [Lays the Lease upon the Table, and looks on the Will.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: He's very wary, yet I fancy I shall be too cunning for him. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l:
Ho, here it is
—The Farm lying—now in Possession of
Samuel Pillage —suffer him to renew his Lease—at the same Rent— Very well, Mr. Pillage, I see my Uncle does mention it, and I'll perform his Will. Give me the Lease—
[ Col. gives it him, he looks upon it, and lays it upon the Table.]
Pray you step to the Door, and call for a Pen and Ink, Mr. Pillage.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I have Pen and Ink in my Pocket, Sir, [Pulls out an Inkhorn.] I never go without that.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l:
I think it belongs to your Profession—
[He looks upon the Pen, while the Col. changes the Lease, and lays down the Contract.]
I doubt this is but a sorry Pen, tho' it may serve to write my Name. [Writes.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Little does he think what he signs. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: There is your Lease, Mr. Pillage, [Gives him the Paper.] Now I must desire you to make what Haste you can down to Coventry, and take Care of every thing, and I'll send down the Undertaker for the Body; do you attend it up, and whatever Charge you are at, I will repay you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You have paid me already, I thank you, Sir. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Will you dine with me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I would rather not, there are some of my Neighbours which I met as I came along, who leaves the Town this Afternoon, they told me, and I should be glad of their Company down.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, well, I won't detain you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I don't care how soon I am out. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will give Orders about Mourning.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You will have Cause to mourn, when you know your Estate imaginary only.

l.hi: You'll find your Hopes and Cares alike are vain,
In Spite of all the Caution you have ta'en,
Fortune rewards the faithful Lover's Pain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l:
Seven Hundred a Year! I wish he had died seventeen Years ago;—What a valuable Collection of Rarities might I have had by this time?—I might
have travell'd over all the known Parts of the Globe, and made my own Closet Rival the Vatican at Rome.— 'Odso, I have a good Mind to begin my Travels now;—let me see,—I am but Sixty! My Father, Grandfather, and Great-Grandfather, reach'd Ninety odd;—I have almost forty Years good:—Let me consider! What will Seven Hundred a Year amount to—in—ay! in thirty Years, I'll say but thirty;—Thirty times Seven, is seven times Thirty—that is—just twenty one thousand Pound,—'tis a great deal of Money,—I may very well reserve sixteen Hundred of it for a Collection of such Rarities, as will make my Name famous to Posterity;—I wou'd not die like other Mortals, forgotten in a Year or two, as my Uncle will be—No.

l.hi: With Nature's curious Works I'll raise my Fame,
That Men, 'till Doom's Day, may repeat my Name.

head.hi:
SCENE changes to a Tavern;
over a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Come Mr. Freeman, here's Mynheer Jan, Van Tim, Tam, Tam;— I shall never think of that Dutchman 's Name.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Mynheer Jan Van Timtamtirelireletta Heer Van Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Ay, Heer Van Fainwell. I never heard such a confounded Name in my Life,—here's his Health I say. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Faith, I never expected to have found so generous a Thing in a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
Oh, he has nothing of the Hollander in his Temper—except an Antipathy to Monarchy—As soon as I told him your Circumstances, he reply'd, he would not be the Ruin of any Man for the World,—and immediately made this Proposal himself:—Let him take what time he will for the Payment,
said he; or if he'll give me his Ward, I'll forgive him the Debt.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Well, Mr. Freeman, I can but thank you,—'Egad you have made a Man of me again; and if ever I lay a Wager more, may I rot in a Goal.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I assure you, Mr. Tradelove, I was very much concern'd, because I was the Occasion,—tho' very innocently I protest.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: I dare swear you was, Mr. Freeman.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Please to have a Lesson of Musick, or a Song, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: A Song? Ay, with all our Hearts; have you ever a merry one?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, my Wife and I can give you a merry Dialogue.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: 'Tis very pretty, Faith.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: There's something for you to drink, Friend, go, lose no Time.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Drawer, and Colonel drest for the Dutch Merchant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ha, Mynheer Tradelove, Ik ben sorry voor your Troubles—maer Ik sal you easie maeken, Ik wil degelt niet hebben.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: I shall for ever acknowledge the Obligation, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: But you understand upon what Condition Mr. Tradelove, Mrs. Lovely.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ya, de juffrow sal al te regt setten; Mynheer.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: With all my Heart, Mynheer, you shall have my Consent to marry her freely.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
Well then, as I am a Party concern'd between you, Mynheer Jan Van Timtamtirelireletta Heer Van Fainwell shall give you a Discharge of your Wager under his own Hand,—and you shall give him your
Consent to marry Mrs. Lovely under yours;—that is the way to avoid all manner of Disputes hereafter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ya, Waeragtig.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Ay, ay, so it is, Mr. Freeman, I'll give it under mine this Minute. [Sits down to write.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And so sal Ik. [Sits down to write.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: So, ho, the House, [Enter Drawer.] Bid your Master come up—I'll see there be Witnesses enough to the Bargain. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: Do you call, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ay, Mr. Sackbut, we shall want your Hand here.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l:
There Mynheer, there's my Consent as amply as you can desire; but you must insert your own Name, for I know not how to spell it; I have left a Blank for it.
[Gives the Colonel a Paper.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ya, Ik sal dat well doen.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Now, Mr. Sackbut, you and I will witness it. [They write.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Daer Mynheer Tradelove is your Discharge. [Gives him a Paper.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l:
Be pleas'd to witness this Receipt too, Gentlemen.
[ Freeman and Sackbut put their Hands.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ay, ay, that we will.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Well, Mynheer, ye most meer doen, ye most Myn voorspraek to de juffrow Syn.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: He means you must recommend him to the Lady.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: That I will, and to the rest of my Brother Guardians.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Wat voor den Duyvel heb you meer Guardians?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Only Three, Mynheer.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Wat donder heb ye Myn betrocken Mynheer? Had Ik that gewoeten, Ik soude eaven met you geweest Syn.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.l: But Mr. Tradelove is the Principal, and he can do a great deal with the rest, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: And he shall use his Interest I promise you Mynheer.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: I will say all that ever I can think on to recommend you, Mynheer, and if you please, I'll introduce you to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Well, dat is waer.—Maer ye must first spreken of, Myn, to de juffrow, and to de oudere Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ay, that's the best way,—and then I and the Heer Van Fainwell will meet you there.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: I will go this Moment, upon Honour,—Your most obedient humble Servant.—My speaking will do you little Good, Minheer, ha, ha; we have bit you, Faith, ha, ha; my Debt's discharg'd,—and for the Man, He'as my Consent—to get her if he can.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, this was a Master-Piece of Contrivance, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: He hugs himself with his supposed good Fortune, and little thinks the Luck's of our Side;—but come, pursue the fickle Goddess while she's in the Mood.—Now for the Quaker.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: That's the hardest Task.

l.hi: Of all the Counterfeits perform'd by Man,
A Soldier makes the simplest Puritan.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head:
SCENE I.
SCENE
's House.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Prim, and Mrs. Lovely in Quakers Dress, meeting.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: SO, now I like thee, Anne: Art thou not better without thy monstrous Hoop Coat and Patches!—If Heaven shou'd make thee so many black Spots upon thy Face, wou'd it not fright thee, Anne?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: If it shou'd turn your Inside outward, and show all the Spots of your Hypocrisy, 'twou'd fright me worse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: My Hypocrisy! I scorn thy Words, Anne, I lay no Baits.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: If you did, you'd catch no Fish.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Well, well, make thy Jests;—but I'd have thee to know, Anne, that I cou'd have catch'd as many Fish (as thou call'st them) in my Time, as ever thou did'st with all thy Fool-Traps about thee.—If Admirers be thy Aim, thou wilt have more of them in this Dress than thy other.—The Men, take my Word for't, are most desirous to see what we are most careful to conceal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Is that the Reason of your Formality, Mrs. Prim? Truth will out: I ever thought, indeed, there was no more Design than Godliness in the pinch'd Cap.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Go, thou art corrupted with reading lude Plays, and filthy Romances,—good for nothing but to lead Youth into the High Road of Fornication.—Ah! I wish thou art not already too familiar with the wicked Ones.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: Too familiar with the wicked Ones! Pray no more of those Freedoms, Madam,—I am familiar with none so wicked as your self;—How dare you talk thus to me! you, you, you unworthy Woman you. [Bursts into Tears.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: What, in Tears, Nancy? What have you done to her, Mrs. Prim, to make her weep?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Done to me! I admire I keep my Senses, among you;—but I will rid my self of your Tyranny, if there be either Law or Justice to be had;—I'll force you to give me up my Liberty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Thou hast more need to weep for thy Sins, Anne,— Yea, for thy manifold Sins.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Don't think that I'll be still the Fool which you have made me,—No, I'll wear what I please—go when and where I please,—and keep what Company I think fit, and not what you shall direct,—I will.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: For my Part, I do think all this very reasonable, Mrs. Lovely,— 'tis fit you should have your Liberty, and for that very purpose I am come.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Periwinkle, and Obediah Prim with a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I have bought some black Stockings of your Husband, Mrs. Prim, but he tells me the Glover's Trade belongs to you, therefore I pray you look me out five or six Dozen of mourning Gloves, such as are given at Funerals, and send them to my House.—

sp.speaker: Ob. Prim.
sp.l: My Friend Periwinkle has got a good Windfall to Day—seven Hundred a Year.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: I wish thee Joy of it, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: What, is Sir Toby dead then?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He is! You'll take care, Mrs. Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Yea, I will, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: This Letter recommendeth a Speaker, 'tis from Aminadab Holdfast of Bristol; peradventure he will be here this Night; therefore Sarah, do thou take care for his Reception.— [Gives her the Letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Prim.
sp.l: I will obey thee.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: What art thou in the Dumps for, Anne?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: We must marry her, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Why truly, if we cou'd find a Husband worth having, I shou'd be as glad to see her married as thou woud'st, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well said, there are but few worth having.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: I can recommend you a Man now, that I think you can none of you have an Objection to!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You recommend? Nay, when ever she marries, I'll recommend the Husband.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: What must it be, a Whale or a Rinoceros, Mr. Periwinkle, ha, ha, ha? Mr. Tradelove, I have a Bill upon you (gives him a Paper) and have been seeking for you all over the Town.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: I'll accept it, Sir Philip, and pay it when due.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He shall be none of the Fops at your End of the Town, with full Perukes and empty Skulls,—nor yet none of your Trading Gentry, who puzzle the Heralds to find Arms for their Coaches,—No, he shall be a Man famous for Travels, Solidity and Curiosity,—one who has search'd into the Profundity of Nature! when Heaven shall direct such a one, he shall have my Consent, because it may turn to the Benefit of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: The Benefit of Mankind! What, wou'd you anatomize me?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Ay, ay, Madam, he wou'd dissect you.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Or, pore over you through a Microscope, to see how your Blood circulates from the Crown of your Head to the Sole of your Foot,—ha, ha! but I have a Husband for you, a Man that knows how to improve your Fortune; one that trades to the four Corners of the Globe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: And wou'd send me for a Venture perhaps.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l:
One that will dress you in all the Pride of
Europe, Asia, Africa
and America— a Dutch Merchant, my Girl.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: A Dutchman! ha, ha, there's a Husband for a fine Lady—Ya Juffrow, will you met myn Slapen—ha, ha; he'll learn you to talk the Language of the Hogs, Madam, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: He'll learn you that one Merchant is of more Service to a Nation, than Fifty Coxcombs.—The Dutch know the Trading Interest to be of more Benefit to the State, than the Landed.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: But what is either Interest to a Lady?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l:
'Tis the Merchant makes the Belle— How would the Ladies sparkle in the Box without the Merchant? The Indian Diamonds! The French Brocade! The Italian Fan! The Flanders Lace! The fine
Dutch Holland!—
How would they vent their Scandal over their Tea-tables? and where would you Beaus have
Champaigne
to toast your Mistresses, were it not for the Merchant?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Verily, Neighbour Tradelove, thou dost waste thy Breath about nothing—All that thou hast said tendeth only to debauch Youth, and fill their Heads with the Pride and Luxury of this World—The Merchant is a very great Friend to Satan, and sendeth as many to his Dominions as the Pope.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Right, I say Knowledge makes the Man.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Yea, but not thy kind of Knowledge—it is the Knowledge of Truth—Search thou for the Light within, and not for Bawbles, Friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l:
Ah, study your Country's Good, Mr.
Periwinkle,
and not her Insects.—Rid you of your homebred
Monsters, before you fetch any from abroad—I dare swear you have Maggots enough in your own Brain to stock all the Virtuoso's in Europe with Butterflies.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: By my Soul, Miss Nancy 's a Wit.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: That is more than she can say by thee, Friend—Look ye, it is in vain to talk, when I meet a Man worthy of her, she shall have my leave to marry him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Provided he be one of the Faithful—Was there ever such a Swarm of Caterpillars to blast the Hopes of a Woman! [Aside.] Know this, that you contend in vain: I'll have no Husband of your chusing, nor shall you lord it over me long—I'll try the Power of an English Senate—Orphans have been redress'd, and Wills set aside—and none did ever deserve their Pity more—Oh Fainwell! where are thy Promises to free me from these Vermin? Alas! the Task was more difficult than he imagin'd!

l.hi: A harder Task than what the Poets tell
She but one Monster fear'd, I've four to fear,

sp.l: And see no Perseus, no Deliv'rer near.

div.stage: Enter Servant, and whispers to Prim.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: One Simon Pure enquireth for thee.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The Woman is mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: So are you all, in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Friend Tradelove, Business requireth my Presence.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Oh, I shan't trouble you—Pox take him for an unmannerly Dog—However, I have kept my Word with my Dutchman, and will introduce him too for all you.

div.stage: Enter Colonel in a Quaker's Habit.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l:
Friend Pure, thou art welcome; how is it with Friend Holdfast, and all Friends in
Bristol? Timothy
Littlewit, John Slenderbrain, and
Christopher Keepfaith?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A goodly Company! [Aside.] They are all in Health, I thank thee for them.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Friend Holdfast writes me Word, that thou camest lately from Pensilvania, how do all Friends there—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What the devil shall I say? I know just as much of Pensilvania as I do of Bristol. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Do they thrive?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Yea, Friend, the Blessing of their good Works fall upon them.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Prim and Mrs. Lovely.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Sarah, know our Friend Pure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Thou art welcome. [He salutes her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Here comes the Sum of all my Wishes—How charming she appears, even in that Disguise? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Why dost thou consider the Maiden so intentively, Friend?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I will tell thee: About four Days ago I saw a Vision—This very Maiden, but in vain Attire, standing on a Precipice; and heard a Voice, which called me by my Name—and bad me put forth my Hand and save her from the Pit—I did so, and me-thought the Damosel grew to my Side.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: What can that portend?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: The Damosel's Conversion—I am perswaded.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: That's false, I'm sure— [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Wilt thou use the Means, Friend Pure?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Means! what Means? Is she not thy Daughter, and already One of the Faithful?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: No, alas! she's One of the Ungodly.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Pray thee mind what this good Man will say unto thee; he will teach thee the Way that thou shouldest walk, Anne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: I know my Way without his Instructions: I hop'd to have been quiet, when once I had put on your odious Formality here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Then thou wearest it out of Compulsion, not Choice, Friend?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Thou art in the right of it, Friend—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Art not thou ashamed to mimick the good Man? Ah! thou art a stubborn Girl.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Mind her not; she hurteth not me—If thou wilt leave her alone with me, I will discuss some few Points with her, that may, perchance, soften her Stubborness, and melt her into Compliance.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Content, I pray thee put it home to her—Come, Sarah, let us leave the good Man with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l:
[Catching hold of Prim, he breaks loose and Exit. ]
What do you mean—to leave me with this old Enthusiastical Canter? Don't think, because I comply'd with your Formality, to impose your ridiculous Doctrine upon me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I pray thee, young Woman, moderate thy Passion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I pray thee, walk after thy Leader, you will but lose your Labour upon me—These Wretches will certainly make me mad.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am of another Opinion; the Spirit telleth me that I shall convert thee, Ann.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: 'Tis a lying Spirit, don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Say'st thou so? Why then thou shalt convert me, my Angel. [Catching her in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: [Shrieks.] Ah! Monster hold off, or I'll tear thy Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Hush! for Heavens sake—dost thou not know me? I am Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l:
Fainwell!
[Enter old Prim. ]
Oh I'm undone! Prim here—I wish with all my Soul I had been dumb. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: What is the Matter? Why didst thou shriek out, Ann?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Shrick out! I'll shriek and shriek again, cry Murder, Thieves, or any thing, to drown the Noise of that Eternal Babbler, if you leave me with him any longer.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Was that all? Fie, fie, Ann.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No matter, I'll bring down her Stomach, I'll warrant thee—leave us, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Fare thee well. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My charming lovely Woman. [Embraces her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l:
What mean'st thou by this Disguise,
Fainwell?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: To set thee free, if thou wilt perform thy Promise.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Make me Mistress of my Fortune, and make thy own Conditions.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
This Night shall answer all thy Wishes—See here, I have the Consent of three of thy Guardians already, and doubt not but Prim shall make the fourth.
[ Prim listening.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: I would gladly hear what Argument the good Man useth to bend her. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Thy Words give me new Life, methinks.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Thou best of Men, Heaven meant to bless me sure, when first I saw thee.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: He hath mollified her—Oh wonderful Conversion!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ha! Prim listening—No more, my Love, we are observ'd; seem to be edify'd, and give 'em Hopes that thou wilt turn Quaker, and leave the rest to me. [Aloud.] I am glad to find that thou art touch'd with what I said unto thee, Ann; another time I will explain the other Article to thee; in the mean while be thou dutiful to our Friend Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I shall obey thee in every thing.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Oh what a prodigious Change is here! Thou hast wrought a Miracle, Friend! Ann, how dost thou like the Doctrine he hath preached?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: So well, that I could talk to him for ever, methinks—I am ashamed of my former Folly, and ask your Pardon, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Enough, enough that thou art sorry, he is no Pope, Ann.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Verily thou dost rejoice me exceedingly, Friend; will it please thee to walk into the next Room, and refresh thy self—Come, take the Maiden by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: We will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: There is another Simon Pure enquireth for thee, Master.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The Devil there is. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Another Simon Pure? I do not know him, is he any Relation of thine?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No, Friend, I know him not—Pox take him, I wish he were in Pensilvania again, with all my Blood. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: What shall I do? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Bring him up.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Humph! then one of us must go down, that's certain—Now Impudence assist me.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: What is thy Will with me, Friend?

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: Didst thou not receive a Letter from Aminadab Holdfast of Bristol, concerning one Simon Pure?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Yea, and Simon Pure is already here, Friend.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And Simon Pure will stay here, Friend, if possible. [Aside.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: That's an Untruth, for I am he.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Take thou heed, Friend, what thou dost say; I do affirm that I am Simon Pure.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: Thy Name may be Pure, Friend, but not that Pure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Yea that Pure, which my good Friend Aminadab Holdfast wrote to my Friend Prim about, the same Simon Pure that came from Pensilvania, and sojourned in Bristol eleven Days; thou would'st not take my
Name from me, would'st thou?—till I have done with it. [Aside.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: Thy Name! I am astonished.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
At what? at thy own Assurance?
[Going up to him, S. Pure starts back.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: Avant, Sathan; approach me not; I defy thee and all thy Works,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Oh, he'll out cant him—Undone, undone for ever. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Hark thee, Friend, thy Sham will not take—Don't exert thy Voice, thou art too well-acquainted with Sathan to start at him, thou wicked Reprobate—What can thy Design be here?

div.stage: [Enter Servant, and gives Prim a Letter.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: One of these must be a Counterfeit, but which I cannot say.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What can that Letter be? [Aside.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: Thou must be the Devil, Friend, that's certain, for no humane Power can stock so great a Falsehood.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l:
This Letter sayeth that thou art better acquainted with that Prince of Darkness, than any here—Read that, I pray thee, Simon.
[Gives it the Col.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
'Tis Freeman 's Hand— [Reads.] There is a Design form'd to rob your House this Night, and cut your Throat, and for that purpose there is a Man disguised like a Quaker, who is to pass for one Simon Pure;
the Gang whereof I am one, tho' now resolv'd to rob no more has been at
Bristol,
one of them came up in the Coach with the Quaker; whose Name he hath taken, and from what he hath gathered from him, formed that Design, and did not doubt but he should impose so far upon you, as to make you turn out the real
Simon Pure, and keep him with you. Make the right Use of this. Adieu.— Excellent well! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l:
Dost thou hear this?
[To S. Pure.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l:
Yea, but it moveth me not; that, doubtless, is the Impostor.
[Pointing at the Col.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Ah! thou wicked one—now I consider thy Face I remember thou didst come up in the Leathern Convenience with me—thou hadst a black Bob-Wig
on, and a brown Camblet Coat with Brass Buttons—canst thou deny it, ha?

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: Yea, I can, and with a safe Conscience too, Friend.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Verily, Friend, thou art the most impudent Villain, I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Nay then, I'll have a Fling at him. [Aside.] I remember the Face of this Fellow at Bath— Ay, this is he that picked my Lady Raffle 's Pocket upon the Grove—Don't you remember that the Mob pump'd you, Friend? This is the most notorious Rogue—

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: What doth provoke thee to seek my Life? Thou wilt not hang me, wilt thou, wrongfully?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: She will do thee no hurt, nor thou shalt do me none; therefore get thee about thy Business Friend, and leave thy wicked Course of Life, or thou may'st not come off so favourably every where.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Go, Friend, I would advise thee, and tempt thy Fate no more.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.l: Yea, I will go, but it shall be to thy Confusion; for I shall clear my self: I will return with some proofs that shall convince thee, Obediah, that thou art highly imposed upon.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Then there will be no staying for me, that's certain—What the Devil shall I do? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: What monstrous Works of Iniquity are there in this World, Simon!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Yea, the Age is full of Vice—Z'death, I am so confounded, I know not what to say. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Thou art disordered, Friend—art thou not well?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
My Spirit is greatly troubled, and something telleth me, that tho' I have wrought a good Work in converting this Maiden, this tender Maiden, yet my Labour will be in vain; for the Evil Spirit fighteth against her; and I see, yea I see with the Eyes of my inward Man, that Sathan will re-buffet her again, whenever I withdraw my self from her; and she will, yea, this very Damosel will return again to that Abomination
from whence I have retrieved her, as if it were, yea as if it were out of the Jaws of the Fiend—hum—

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Good lack! thinkest thou so?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I must second him. [Aside.] What meaneth this Struggling within me? I feel the Spirit resisting the Vanities of this World, but the Flesh is rebellious, yea the Flesh—I greatly fear the Flesh, and the Weakness thereof—hum—

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: The Maid is inspir'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Behold, her Light begins to shine forth—Excellent Woman! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: This good Man hath spoken Comfort unto me, yea Comfort, I say; because the Words which he hath breathed into my outward Ears, are gone thro' and fixed in mine Heart, yea verily in mine Heart, I say,—and I feel the Spirit doth love him exceedingly, hum—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: She acts it to the Life. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Prodigious! the Damosel is filled with the Spirit. Sarah!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: I am greatly rejoic'd to see such a Change in our beloved Anne— I came to tell thee that Supper stayeth for thee.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am not disposed for thy Food, my Spirit longeth for more delicious Meat;—fain would I redeem this Maiden from the Tribe of Sinners, and break those Cords asunder wherewith she is bound—Hum—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Something whispers in my Ears, methinks,—that I must be subject to the Will of this good Man, and from him only must hope for Consolation,—Hum—it also telleth me that I am a chosen Vessel to raise up Seed to the Faithful, and that thou must consent that we two be one Flesh according to the Word—hum—

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: What a Revelation is here? This is certainly Part of thy Vision, Friend, this is the Maiden's growing to thy Side; Ah! with what Willingness shou'd I give thee my Consent, could I give thee her Fortune too,—but thou wilt never get the Consent of the wicked Ones.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I wish I was as sure of yours. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: My Soul rejoiceth, yea, it rejoiceth, I say, to find the Spirit within thee; for lo, it moveth thee with natural Agitation,—yea, with natural Agitation, I say again, and stirreth up the Seeds of thy Virgin-Inclination towards this good Man—yea, it stirreth, as one may say,—yea verily, I say it stirreth up thy Inclination—yea, as one would stir a Pudding.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I see, I see! the Spirit guiding of thy Hand, good Obediah Prim, and now behold thou art signing thy Consent;—and now I see my self within thy Arms, my Friend and Brother, yea, I am become Bone of thy Bone, and Flesh of thy Flesh [Embraces him] Hum—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Admirably perform'd [Aside.] And I will take thee in all spiritual Love for an Helpmate, yea, for the Wife of my Bosom,—and now, methinks—I feel a Longing,—yea, a longing, I say for the Consummation of thy Love,—yea, I do long exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: And, verily, verily, my Spirit feeleth the same Longing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: The Spirit hath greatly mov'd them both,—Friend Prim, thou must consent, there is no resisting of the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l:
Yea, the Light within sheweth me, that I shall fight a good Fight—and wrestle thro' those reprobate Fiends, thy other Guardians—yea, I perceive the Spirit will hedge thee into the Flock of the Righteous,—Thou art a chosen Lamb—yea a chosen Lamb, and I will not push thee back—no, I will not, I say—no, thou shalt leap-a, and frisk-a, and skip-a, and bound, and bound, I say—yea, bound within the Fold of the righteous—yea even within thy Fold, my Brother—
Fetch me the Pen and Ink, Sarah— and my Hand shall confess its Obedience to the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I wish it were over.

div.stage: [Enter Mrs. Prim with Pen and Ink.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: I tremble lest this quaking Rogue should return and spoil all. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l:
Here Friend, do thou write what the Spirit prompteth, and I will sign it.
[ Col. sits down.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Verily, Anne, it greatly rejoiceth me, to see thee reformed from that original Wickedness wherein I found thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I do believe thou art, and I thank thee.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
[Reads.]
This is to certifie all whom it may concern, that I do freely give up all my Right and Title in
Anne Lovely to Simon Pure,
and my full Consent that she shall become his Wife, according to the Form of Marriage. Witness my Hand.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: That is enough—give me the Pen. [Signs it.

div.stage: Enter Betty running to Mrs. Lovely.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Oh! Madam, Madam, here's the Quaking Man again, he has brought a Coachman and two or three more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l:
Ruin'd past Redemption!
[Aside to Col.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
No, no, one Minute sooner had spoil'd all, but now—here is Company coming, Friend, give me the Paper.
[Going up to Prim hastily.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Here it is, Simon, and I wish thee happy with the Maiden.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: 'Tis done, and now Devil do thy worst.

sp.speaker: Sim. Pu.
sp.l: Look thee, Friend, I have brought these People to satisfy thee that I am not that Impostor which thou didest take me for, this is the Man that did drive the Leathern Conveniency, that brought me from Bristol,— and this is.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Look ye, Friend, to save the Court the Trouble of examining Witnesses—I plead guilty,—ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: How's this? is not thy Name Pure, then?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No really, Sir, I only made bold with this Gentleman's Name;—but I here give it up safe and found, it has done the Business which I had occasion for, and now I intend to wear my own, which shall be at his Service upon the same Occasion at any Time: ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sim. Pu.
sp.l: Oh! the Wickedness of this Age.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.l: Then you have no farther need of us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No, honest Man, you may go about your Business.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: I am struck dumb with thy Impudence, Anne, thou hast deceived me,—and perchance undone thy self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.l: Thou art a dissembling Baggage, and Shame will overtake thee.

sp.speaker: Sim. Pur.
sp.l: I am grieved to see thy Wife so much troubled; I will follow and console her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Thy Brother Guardians enquireth for thee; there is another Man with them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l:
Who can that other Man be?
[To the Col.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: 'Tis one Freeman, a Friend of mine, whom I order'd to bring the rest of thy Guardians here.

div.stage: Enter Sir Philip, Tradelove, Periwinkle and Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l:
[To the Col. ]
Is all safe? did my Letter do you Service?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: All, all's safe! ample Service. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Miss Nancy, how do'st do, Child?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.l: Don't call me Miss, Friend Philip, my Name is Anne, thou knowest.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: What, is the Girl metamorphos'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: I wish thou wert so metamorphos'd. Ah! Philip, throw off that gaudy Attire, and wear the Clothes becoming of thy Age.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: I am ashamed to see these Men. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: My Age! the Woman is possess'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No, thou art possess'd rather, Friend.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Hark ye, Mrs. Lovely, one Word with you. [Takes hold of her Hand.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: This Maiden is my Wife, thanks to Friend Prim, and thou hast no Business with her. [Takes her from him.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: His Wife! hark ye, Mr. Freeman.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why you have made a very fine Piece of Work of it, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Married to a Quaker! thou art a fine Fellow to be left Guardian to an Orphan truly—there's a Husband for a young Lady!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: When I have put on my Beau-Cloaths, Sir Philip, you'll like me better.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Thou wilt make a very scurvy Beau, Friend.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I believe I can prove it under your Hand, that you thought me a very fine Gentleman in the Park to-day, about thirty six Minutes after Eleven; will you take a Pinch, Sir Philip— out of the finest Snuff-Box you ever saw. [Offers him Snuff.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! I am overjoy'd, faith I am, if thou be'st the Gentleman,—I own I did give my Consent to the Gentleman I brought here to-day,—but if this is he I can't be positive.

sp.speaker: Ob. Prim.
sp.l: Canst thou not—Now I think thou art a fine Fellow to be left Guardian to an Orphan—Thou shallow-brain'd Shuttlecock, he may be a Pick-pocket for ought thou dost know.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You would have been two rare Fellows to have been trusted with the sole Management of her Fortune, would ye not, think ye? But, Mr. Tradelove and my self, shall take Care of her Portion.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l:
Ay, ay, so we will. Did not you tell me the Dutch Merchant desired me to meet him here, Mr.
Freeman?—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I did so, and I am sure he will be here, if you'll have a little Patience.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
What, is Mr. Tradelove impatient? nay then, ik ben gereet voor you, heb ye,
Jan van Timtamtirelireletta Heer van Fainwell,
vergeeten?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Oh! pox of the Name! What have you trick'd me too, Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Trick'd, Mr. Tradelove! did I not give you Two thousand Pound for your Consent fairly? and now do you tell a Gentlemen that he has trick'd you?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: So, so, you are a pretty Guardian, faith, sell your Charge; what, did you look upon her as part of your Stock?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! I am glad thy Knavery is found out however,—I confess the Maiden over-reach'd me, and no sinister End at all.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ay, ay, one thing or another over-reach'd you all—but I'll take care he shall never finger a Penny ofher Money, I warrant you,—Over-reach'd quoth'a? Why I might have been over-reach'd too, if I had had no more Wit: I don't know but this very Fellow may be him that was directed to me from Grand Cairo to-day. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The very same, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Are you so, Sir? but your Trick would' not pass upon me.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No, as you say, at that Time it did not, that was not my lucky Hour;—but hark ye, Sir, I must let you into one Secret—you may keep honest John Tradescant 's Coat on, for your Uncle Sir Toby Periwinkle is not dead,—so the Charge of Mourning will be saved, ha, ha,—don't you remember Mr. Pillage your Uncle's Steward, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Not dead! I begin to fear I am trick'd too.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Don't you remember the signing of a Lease, Mr. Periwinkle?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, and what signifies that Lease, if my Uncle is not dead? ha! I am sure it was a Lease I sign'd.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Ay, but it was a Lease for Life, Sir, and of this beautiful Tenement, I thank you.
[Taking hold of Mrs. Lovely.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, Neighbours Fare!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: So then, I find you are all trick'd, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am certain I read as plain a Lease as ever I read in my Life.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You read a Lease I grant you, but you sign'd this Contract. [Shewing a Paper.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l:
How durst you put this Trick upon me Mr.
Free man?
did not you tell me my Uncle was dying?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: And would tell you twice as much to serve my Friend, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: What the learned, famous Mr. Periwinkle chous'd too—ha, ha, ha!—I shall dye with laughing, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: It had been well if her Father had left her to wiser Heads than thine and mine, Friend, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: Well, since you have outwitted us all, pray you what, and who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.l: Sir, the Gentleman is a fine Gentleman.—I am glad you have got a Person, Madam, who understands Dress and good Breeding,—I was resolved she should have a Husband of my chusing.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.l: I am sorry the Maiden is fallen into such Hands.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.l: A Beau! nay then she is finely help'd up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.l: Why Beaus are great Encouragers of Trade, Sir, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l:
Look ye, Gentlemen,—I am the Person who can give the best Account of my self, and I must beg Sir Philip 's Pardon, when I tell him that I have as much Aversion to what he calls Dress and Breeding, as I have to the Enemies of my Religion. I have had the Honour to serve his Majesty, and headed a Regiment of the bravest Fellows that ever push'd Bayonet in the Throat of a Frenchman; and, notwithstanding the Fortune
this Lady brings me, whenever my Country wants my Aid, this Sword and Arm are at her Service.

l.hi: And now, my Fair, if you'll but deign to smile,
I meet a Recompence for all my Toil:
Love and Religion ne'er admit Restraint,
Force makes many a Sinner, not one Saint;
Still free as Air the active Mind does rove,
And searches proper Objects for its Love;
But that once fix'd, 'tis past the Power of Art,
To chase the dear Ideas from the Heart:
'Tis Liberty of Choice that sweetens Life,
Makes the glad Husband, and the happy Wise.

div.head:
EPILOGUE,
Written by Mr. SEWELL.
Spoken by Mrs. BƲLLOCK.

l.hi: W
HAT new strange Ways our Modern
Beaus devise!
What Tryals of Love-Skill to gain the Prize!
The Heathen Gods, who never matter'd Rapes,
Scarce wore such strange Variety of Shapes:
The Devil take their odious barren Skulls,
To court in Form of Snakes and filthy Bulls.

div.l: Old Jove once nick'd it, I am told,

l.hi: In a whole Lapful of true Standard Gold;

div.l: How must his Godship then Fair Danaë warm?

l.hi: In trucking Ware for Ware there is no Harm.

div.l: Well, after all—that Money has a Charm:

l.hi: But now indeed that stale Invention's past:
Besides, you know, that Guineas fall so fast,
Poor Nymph must come to Pocket-Piece at last.

div.l: Old Harry's Face, or good Queen Bess's Ruff,

l.hi: Not that I'd take 'em—may do well enough;
No—my ambitious Spirit's far above
Those little Tricks of Mercenary Love.
That Man be mine, who, like the Colonel here,
Can top his Character in every Sphere;
Who can a thousand Ways employ his Wit,
Out-promise Statesmen, and out-cheat a Cit;
Beyond the Colours of a Trav'ler paint,
And cant, and ogle too—beyond a Saint.
The last Disguise most pleas'd me, I confess,
There's something tempting in the preaching Dress;
And pleas'd me more than once a Dame of Note,
Who lov'd her Husband in his Footman's Coat.
To see one Eye in wanton Motions play'd,
Th'other to the Heavenly Regions stray'd,
As if it for its Fellow's Frailties pray'd.
But yet I hope, for all that I have said,
To find my Spouse a Man of War in Bed.
